column1: #Text=This repo contains the implementation of our paper [Sparse and Noisy LiDAR Completion with RGB Guidance and Uncertainty](https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.05356) by [Wouter Van Gansbeke](https://github.com/wvangansbeke), Davy Neven, Bert De Brabandere and Luc Van Gool.
#Text=If you find this interesting or relevant to your work, consider citing:
#Text=    author={Van Gansbeke, Wouter and Neven, Davy and De Brabandere, Bert and Van Gool, Luc},
#Text=    booktitle={2019 16th International Conference on Machine Vision Applications (MVA)},
#Text=    title={Sparse and Noisy LiDAR Completion with RGB Guidance and Uncertainty},
#Text=This software is released under a creative commons license which allows for personal and research use only.
#Text=For a commercial license please contact the authors.
#Text=Monocular depth prediction methods fail to generate absolute and precise depth maps and stereoscopic approaches are still significantly outperformed by LiDAR based approaches.
#Text=The goal of the depth completion task is to generate dense depth predictions from sparse and irregular point clouds.
#Text=This project makes use of uncertainty to combine multiple sensor data in order to generate accurate depth predictions.
#Text=Mapped lidar points together with RGB images (monocular) are used in this framework.
#Text=This method holds the **1st place** entry on the [KITTI depth completion benchmark](http://www.cvlibs.net/datasets/kitti/eval_depth.php?
#Text=benchmark=depth_completion) at the time of submission of the paper.
#Text=The contribution of this paper is threefold:
#Text=* Global and local information are combined in order to accurately complete and correct the sparse and noisy LiDAR input.
#Text=Monocular RGB images are used for the guidance of this depth completion task.
#Text=* Confidence maps are learned for the global branch and the local branch in an unsupervised manner.
#Text=The predicted depth maps are weighted by their respective confidence map.
#Text=This is the late fusion technique used in our framework.
#Text=* This method ranks first on the KITTI depth completion benchmark without using additional data or postprocessing.
#Text=The predictions of our model for the KITTI test set can be downloaded [here](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1U7dvH4sC85KRVuV19fRpaMzJjE-m3D9x).
#Text=The most important packages are pytorch, torchvision, numpy, pillow and matplotlib.
#Text=First download the dataset of the depth completion.
#Text=Secondly, you'll need to unzip and download the camera images from kitti.
#Text=I used the file `download_raw_files.sh`, but this is at your own risk.
#Text=Make sure you understand it, otherwise don't use it.
#Text=If you want to keep it safe, go to kitti's website.
#Text=The complete dataset consists of 85898 training samples, 6852 validation samples, 1000 selected validation samples and 1000 test samples.
#Text=This step is optional, but allows you to transform the images to jpgs and to downsample the original lidar frames.
#Text=This will create a new dataset in $dest.
#Text=You can find the required preprocessing in:
#Text=(Firstly, I transformed the png's to jpg - images to save place.
#Text=Secondly, two directories are built i.e. one for training and one for validation.
#Text=- Set flag "input_type" to rgb or depth.
#Text=- Set flag "pretrained" to true or false to use a model pretrained on Cityscapes for the global branch.
#Text=checkout more details in the bash file.
#Text=You can find the model pretrained on Cityscapes [here](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1U7dvH4sC85KRVuV19fRpaMzJjE-m3D9x?
#Text=This model is used for the global network.
#Text=You can find a fully trained model and its corresponding predictions for the KITTI test set [here](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1U7dvH4sC85KRVuV19fRpaMzJjE-m3D9x?
#Text=The RMSE is around 802 mm on the selected validation set for this model as reported in the paper.
#Text=Save the model in a folder in the `Saved` directory.
#Text=(You might have to recompile the C files for testing, provided by KITTI, if your architecture is different from mine)
#Text=- I recently increased the stability of the training process and I also made the convergence faster by adding some skip connections between the global and local networks.

#Text=Initially I only used guidance by multiplication with an attention map (=probability), but found out that it is less robust and that differences between a focal MSE and vanilla MSE loss function were now negligible.
#Text=Be aware that this change will alter the appearance of the confidence maps since fusion happens at mutliple stages now
#Text=- Feel free to experiment with different architectures for the global or local network.
#Text=It is easy to add new architectures to `Models/__init__.py`
#Text=- I used a Tesla V100 GPU for evaluation.
#Text=This work was supported by Toyota, and was carried out at the TRACE Lab at KU Leuven (Toyota Research on Automated Cars in Europe - Leuven)
